messages.message:
*Jupyter Notebook as a Production Code, Doc, Test Authoring Env*

I'm not sure what the right channel for this is, but I wanted to alert folks to a project that I think is 100% worth playing with if you're interested in "_developer toolery_".

I've been messing with it for a few weeks now, and my confidence that it's a productive way to code is every bit as high as my hunch when I first saw it.

It's called *NBDev* and it's incredibly simple: it's just a set of scripts and conventions to write (1) code, (2) documentation, and (3) tests in a Python notebook and run a script that (1) auto-builds a PIP module from that notebook for production, (2) auto-builds documentation, and (3) auto-runs tests.

http://nbdev.fast.ai/

It might be interesting to think of ways we could both use it ourselves, but also weave it into our product
This is really interesting — do you have an environment or setup where we can try to test this ourselves? Maybe you have a link to a working Notebook? @Ted

After installing nbdev on your local machine, you can just use this link to clone yourself an example repo set up to use it:

https://github.com/fastai/nbdev_template/generate

here's the link on Github for viewing but not using:

https://github.com/fastai/nbdev_template
The second version of FastAI has been developed entirely with this process. You can see their notebooks here

By developing in these notebooks, everything else (their PIP modules, their tests, and their documentation website) are 100% auto-generated, and the coding experience is one that co-locates all these resources together
I realize I'm prone to romanticizing things. But I seriously don't think I can look at development the same way after spending time in this environment.
(Note: It's not strictly better. Like anything it comes with trade-offs. It's a very different way to manage development.)

Gotcha — any reason why we can’t set this up in our current Notebooks — what is missing from our Notebooks that requires us to have to use local dev here? (asking to see if we can bridge the gap with our current Notebook deployment)
